_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Cheese Protien Internation LLC facility contains 1 refrigeration system process which uses Anhydrous Ammonia. The maximum amount of anhydrous ammonia contained in the process is 35,000 pounds. The anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system is a vapor compression system which consists of four basic components; the compressor, condenser, expansion valve, and evaporator.  The cycle involves two pressures, high and low, which enables the system to produce a continuous cooling effect.  Low pressure vapor is compressed, raising temperatures and pressure levels.  During compression, heat of compression is added to the vapor as the pressure is raised.  At the condenser, the high pressure vapor is liquefied by cooling.  The liquid ammonia flows from the condenser to an expansion valve where its pressure and temperature are reduced.  The ammonia moves to the evaporator where it absorbs heat from the media being cooled.  Vaporized ammonia then flows to the compressor suction to complete the refrigeration cycle.
 
The ammonia vapors from the evapoatros flow through a liquid accumulator where any entrained liquids are knocked out of the gas stream prior to being compressed.  This prevents damage to the compressors.  The accumulated liquids are transfered back to the receiver.

The Cheese Protein International LLC refrigeration system is a closed loop system and designed to run continuously.  When required, the refrigeration system is recharged with ammonia by off-loaded bulk ammonia to the ammonia receiver.  Ammonia is off-loaded through the tanker's flexible hose connected to the receiver's hard piped charge line.  Recharging only occurs when there has been a loss of ammonia from the system.  Under normal operation, these losses result from fugitive sources (i.e., pump seals, valves, flanges) and from routine maintenance of equipment.

Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams;
 
Comprehensive and up to date piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) for the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system are maintained by the Plant Engineer.  

Ventilation System Design;

The facility has one ammonia refrigeration engine room.  The engine room ventilation system consists of three air intake areas and three exhaust fans.   One exhaust fan in the engine room is run continuously. When ammonia is detected at a concentration of 300 PPM the detector automatically activates the emergency ventilation exhaust fans. The ventilation system design data is maintained by the Plant Engineer.

Safety Systems;

Ammonia sensors and control panels are installed in the engine room and automatically activate the ventilation system and audible /visual alarms inside and outside the engine room. A sail switch is provided on the engine rooms continuous exhaust fan.  If the fan fails to operate properly, the sail switch activates an audible/visual alarm inside and outside the engine room.

Safety systems design data are maintained by the Plant Engineer.

Information Pertaining to the Hazards of Ammonia are contained in the MSDS for anhydrous ammonia.  The MSDS meets the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.1200 (g).  This information is also provided as part of each Maintenance Departments Ammonia Refrigeration System Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) Manual.

Materials of Construction;

Information on the materials of construction is provided in the facility refrigeration system specifications and on construction drawings maintained by the Plant Engineer.  

Electrical Classification;

The engine room and plant are not managed as classified areas.  The engine rooms has a ventilation system that meet current ASHRAE ventilation standards, which exempts the engine rooms from being operated as a classified area. Ventilation system design data is maintained by the Plant Engineer.

Material and Energy Balances;

Material and energy balances have been developed for the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system and are maintained by the Plant Engineer.

Relief System Design;

The facilities refrigeration system anhydrous ammonia relief system is designed in accordance with ANSI/ASHRAE standard 15-2001 specifications and are contained on construction drawings maintained by the Plant Engineer.  
 
Design Codes and Standards;

2001 Uniform Mechanical Code; Chapter 15, Mechanical Refrigeration Equipment

1988 Uniform Fire Code; Article 63, Mechanical Refrigeration Article 80, Hazardous Materials

ASME/ANSI B31.3-1999 Edition; Process Piping

ASME B31.3 - 1999 Edition; 345 Testing

ANSI/ASHRAE 15 A?2001; Safety Standard for Mechanical Refrigeration

ANSI/IIAR2 A? 1999; Equipment Design, and Installation of Ammonia Mechanical 
Refrigerating Systems

IIAR Bulletin No. R1-1983; Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia 
Refrigeration System

IIAR Bulletin No. 107 A? 1997; Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When 
Making Ammonia Refrigeration Plant Tie-Ins

IIAR Bulletin No. 108; Water Contamination in Ammonia Refrigeration Systems

IIAR Bulletin No. 109 A? 1997; IIAR Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe 
Ammonia Refrigeration System

IIAR Bulletin No. 111 A? 1991; Ammonia Machinery Room Ventilation

IIAR Bulletin No. 112 A? 1998; Ammonia Machinery Room Design

IIAR Bulletin No. 114 A? 1991; Identification of Ammonia Refrigeration Piping and System Components

IIAR Bulletin No. 116 A? 1992; Avoiding Component Failure in Industrial 
Refrigeration Systems Caused by Abnormal Pressure or Shock

Good Engineering Practices;

The Cheese Protein International LLC facility believes that the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system located at this facility is designed and operated following good engineering practices.  The potential hazards associated with this operation have been identified through a formal process hazard assessment and any action items will be addressed in a timely manner.

Written Operating Procedures;

Written Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's) for the faciliy's anhydrous ammonia refrigeration process have been developed in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (29 CFR Part 1910.119). The facilities SOP's provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in the covered process, consistent with the process safety information. The operating  procedures include the following information:  

A? Steps involved in initial startup; startup after an emergency shutdown or turnaround; normal operations; temporary operations; normal shutdown; and emergency operations and shutdown procedures, including the condition under which shut down is required and the assignment of emergency shutdown responsibilities to qualified personnel.

A? Process conditions and operating steps necessary for safe operation.  

A? Consequences of deviations and responses to correct or avoid deviations from the process limits for safe operation.  

A? Release information, such as the properties and hazards of materials used in the process, precautions to prevent exposures, remedial actions for a release, any special or unique hazards, and procedures for quality control of raw materials and hazardous chemical inventories.  

A? Functions of safety systems.  

A? Safe work practices, for activities such as lockout/tagout, confined-space entry, line breaking and vessel opening, and control over personnel entering and exiting a facility.  

The operating procedures are readily accessible to the operators and are reviewed as often as necessary to ensure that they remain current.  The accuracy of the procedure is certified annually. 
 
Mechanical Integrity;

Written procedures have been developed to ensure the mechanical integrity of the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration process equipment, including pressure vessels, storage tanks, pumps, piping systems, relief systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, alarms, and interlocks.  These procedures include the following:

A? Tests and inspections to be performed and their frequency;

A? Training for maintenance personnel in the above-described procedures and an overview of the process and its hazards;

A? Test and inspection documentation, including the date of the test or inspection, the name of the person performing the task, the identity of the equipment, the task performed, and the results of the test or inspection;

A? Procedures for correcting deficiencies either:  (1) before further use of the equipment, or (2) in a timely manner when precautions are taken to ensure continued safe operation; and 

A? Quality control procedures to ensure maintenance equipment, materials, and spare parts meet design specifications and are properly utilized.

The tests, inspections, and their frequency are based on manufacturers recommendations, codes and standards, or good engineering practice.
Presently, the following maintenance activities are conducted:

A? The system performance is reviewed during each operating shift and system parameters are logged.  Maintenance personnel walk through the facility three times daily to visually inspect the system.  If anything unusual is noted it is either immediately repaired, or a work order is generated to initiate the repair or modifications.

A? Any unusual performance or ammonia odors are promptly investigated by maintenance personnel.  

A? Parts are only replaced with their identical components unless authorization is given by the Plant Engineer and a Management of Change form is completed.  

A? Copies of equipment information are kept in the Maintenance office.  

A? Associates involved in the PM program are trained in the anhydrous ammonia processes and hazards.  The maintenance staff is trained by more experienced staff that is qualified in the maintenance and operation of the equipment.

A? Deficiencies are corrected as required to maintain a safe working environment.  Maintenance materials, spare parts, and equipment have been reviewed for compatibility with the anhydrous ammonia processes.

A? The facility is insured for fire.  The fire protection system including fire extinguishers are inspected each year.  The boilers are insured and inspected annually by an outside contractor.  Pressure vessels are inspected annually by the insurer.

Equipment maintenance records are kept in the maintenance office.  The records are kept indefinitely.  

Access Control Procedures;

The Facility is fenced and gated, access is restricted to authorized personnel only by a manned 24 hour guard. Exterior doors to the engine room are locked.

Contractors;

The management of contractors working within the facility is a significant part of the prevention program.  The facility has a comprehensive contractor management program.  The contractor management program begins with an initial screening of the contractor.  Then, maintenance management personnel are assigned to oversee each aspect of contractor management.  The following elements summarize the main points of the facility's contractor management program:

All contractors must supply required information to complete the facilities Contractor Pre-Qualification Checklist prior to being approved for work.

All ammonia refrigeration contractors are assigned an internal manager.

Contractors are required to check in each day.

Contractors are required to follow all facility environmental, health, and safety rules or are subject to dismissal.  Each contract work area is monitored periodically for health and safety compliance by the area supervisor.  

Contractor is escorted to work area the first day and monitored by Dairyman's staff throughout the project.

Periodically during large projects, or at the conclusion of smaller ones, each contractor is evaluated (using a Contractor Safety Performance Evaluation Form) for compliance with safety requirements.  Based upon this performance assessment, a decision is made as to whether the contractor will be permitted to remain on the bid list.

All contract employees working on the anhydrous ammonia system receive a comprehensive site orientation session covering topics contained in the Contractor Orientation Checklist.  

All hazardous work performed by the contractor requiring the completion of permits (e.g., hot work, lockout /tagout, etc.) is conducted in accordance with the facility procedures.  

Contractors must make a verbal report by the end of the shift, and produce a written report to the Facility Safety Manager of any injuries; vehicle incidents; and incidents involving damage to property, spills, fires, theft, or loss of equipment, prior to the end of the next working day.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews;

The facility conducts pre-startup safety reviews (PSSRs) on any new or modified equipment at the facility to confirm that the as-built installation meets the design specifications. That adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place, and that operators are trained in these procedures before starting of the equipment.


Management of Change Procedures;

The facility has developed modification control procedures to be used when the technical basis of a design and/or the equipment design basis changes.  These procedures apply to any additions, deletions, or modifications to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and operating procedures.  However, these procedures do not apply to replacements in kind (RIK).  

The modification control procedures ensure and document that the following issues are addressed prior to making any change:  

The technical basis of the proposed change,

Any related safety and health considerations,

Any necessary operating procedure modifications,

The necessary time period for making the proposed change, and 

Required authorizations for the proposed changes.

All personnel affected by the change, including contract employees, must be trained in and informed of the change before the implementation of the change.  For changes involving operating procedures and process safety information, the procedures and process safety information must be updated. 

Hot Work Program;

This facility has developed a system for issuing permits for all hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process (e.g., process involving anhydrous ammonia).  The permit (1) documents compliance with OSHA's fire prevention and protection requirements, which are presented in 29 CFR 1910.252(a); (2) identifies the time period authorized for hot work; and (3) identifies the equipment on which the hot work is to be performed.  The permit must be issued before the start of the hot work and must be kept at the site where the hot work will be performed. 

Facility Permit System;

Hot work is any activity within an area that could potentially produce a spark or involve an open flame.  The Hot Work Policy and Permit System  outlines the requirements and responsibilities associated with conducting hot work at the facility.  The facility maintains an effective hot work permit procedure as part of an overall hot work system.  The written program for hot work contains the following:
  
The Plant Engineer, Maintenance Manager/Foreman, Production Supervisor, PSM Coordinator or the EHS are qualified to authorize the performance of hot work.

A list of locations where hot work permits are required (or hot work permits are not required). 

A training program for associates designated to authorize hot work (e.g., maintenance and operating personnel).  This training program includes specific instructions on:

The types of hazards to look for, precautions that can be taken, and locations and situations in which hot work is prohibited; 

The use, calibration, and limitation of lower explosive limit (LEL) monitoring equipment; 

When cutting and welding is permitted;

Location of fire safe areas;

Safeguards used while cutting, welding and using open flame;

Proper use of fire extinguisher;

Understanding of inspection area before and after work completed;

Maintenance of cutting and welding equipment;

Use of Permit; and

Use of combustible gas detection instruments.

Hot work permit applications are available in the maintenance shop.  Approved and/or completed hot work permits are maintained in the office of the Maintenance Manager for one year after the job has been completed.

Incident Investigation:

Cheese Protein International LLC incident investigation procedures have been developed to investigate catastrophic releases of a highly hazardous chemical in the workplace or situations that could have resulted in such a catastrophic release.  These procedures include the following required activities:  

Initiate the investigation as soon as possible and no later than within 48 hours of the incident.

Establish an incident investigation team that includes:  (1) at least one person knowledgeable about the subject process; (2) other individuals with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly analyze and investigate the incident; and (3) a contract employee, if the incident involved a contractor.

Prepare an incident report for each incident.  This report must include:  

The date of the incident,

The date the investigation began,

A description of the incident,

A description of the  contributing factors, and 

Any recommendations resulting from the investigation.  

Establish a system for resolving the recommendations of the incident investigation team and documenting any resolutions adopted or corrective actions taken.  

Review the report with all affected personnel, including contract employees.  

All incident investigation reports must be retained for five years.  

Facility Program;

An incident is defined as any unplanned event resulting in or that could have resulted in a spill or release of anhydrous ammonia.  The management elements of the facility program include the following: 

All process incidents are formally and promptly investigated.  Each incident is a learning experience that may result in changes in standard operating procedures (SOPs), process safety information, and training programs.  

All incident investigation reports include a means of preventing future occurrence of the incident, and a written follow-up report is prepared.  

All incident investigation reports are disseminated to those who work in or near the incident area, and are reviewed during safety training classes and safety meetings.  

Responsibilities;

The PSM Coordinator is responsible for organizing an incident investigation team and conducting the initial meeting.  The Cheese Protein International Safety Committee and selected employees act as the investigative team.  The PSM Coordinator is responsible for leading the investigation and completing an Incident Investigation Summary Report.

The Cheese Protein International LLC Plant and Maintenance Manager as well as the Plant Engineer are responsible for reviewing the Incident Investigation Summary Report.

The manager of the area where the incident occurred is responsible for participating in the incident investigation, fully considering the remedial activities, and accomplishing those activities that are agreed upon in a timely manner.  The manager of the incident area and others with assignments are responsible for reporting periodically on the progress regarding the implementation of recommendations.  

Location;

All incident investigation reports and progress reports are maintained in the PSM CoordinatorA?s office for at least five years.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Saputo Cheese USA Inc. has developed, implemented and updated its Risk Management Program (RMP) and Process Safety Management (PSM) in accordance with the standards of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) (40 CFR Part 68), Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) (29 CFR 1910.119) and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (CCR, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5).  All elements of these standards have been combined to create one program document herein referred to as the A?RMPA?.

SaputoA?s RMP is comprised of the following sections which are summarized below.

1.    Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies
2.    Stationary source and the regulated substances handled
3.    Worst-case and alternative release scenarios
4.    General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention
5.    Five-year accident history
6.    Emergency response program
7.    Planned changes to improve safety
8.    Seismic assessment


1.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Saputo is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is inherent to a comprehensive accidental release prevention program in place that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  If such a release does occur, our employees are trained to follow the Emergency Action Plan and to evacuate the facility as necessary.  We are also coordinated with the City of Tulare Fire Department and the Tulare County Environmental Health, which provide additional emergency response expertise.


2.  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Our facility's primary activity encompasses cheese manufacturing.  The plant is located at 800 East Paige Avenue in Tulare, California.  There is one RMP-regulated subst

ance, anhydrous ammonia, used at the plant to provide refrigeration for production and warehousing.  The maximum inventory of ammonia at our facility is 37,348 pounds.


 
3.  WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

The worst-case scenario (WCS) is defined as the release of the largest quantity of ammonia from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint.  For the WCS, the high pressure receiver and associated piping, containing approximately 3,966 pounds and limited by administrative controls (written procedures), was assumed to have released its contents over a 10-minute period.

The alternative release scenario (ARS) is one that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario.  For the ARS, a one-quarter inch effective diameter hole in a high side (e.g. 180 psig) pipe would result in a release 133.5 pounds of ammonia per minute.  To limit the duration of the release, plant personnel would use controls and mitigation system within 10 minutes of leak detection.


4.  GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION

The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our facility.

Process Safety Information

Saputo maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the refrigeration process.

Process Hazard Analysis

Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is a combination of the HAZOP study and the What-If/Checklist.  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of five years or when changes dictate.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Standard Operating Procedures

S

aputo maintains written standard operating procedures (SOP) for covered processes.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround for each system component.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Training

Saputo ensures that operators are trained and understand the SOPs associated with the processes.  Refresher training is provided at least once every three years and more frequently as needed.  The employees are also trained in the Emergency Action Plan annually.  All training is to be validated and documented for each employee.

Mechanical Integrity

Saputo performs documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operation.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance is performed by qualified personnel, either in-house or by a contractor, who have the appropriate training suited to their responsibilities.  Any identified equipment deficiencies are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change

Written procedures are in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose duties are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly notified and offered training to deal with the modification.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as required.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits

These audits are carried out o

nce every three (3) years to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  Any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation

Saputo promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release.  These investigations are conducted to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent a future release.  All reports are retained for a minimum of five (5) years.

Employee Participation

Saputo truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP, including information resulting from process hazard analyses.

Contractors

Saputo hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is performed.  Saputo has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related the contractor's work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.


5.  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Saputo has had a good record of preventing accidental releases over the last five years.  Due to our stringent release prevention policies, no incidents, as defined by the RMP rule, have occurred in the past five years.


6.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

Saputo developed an Emergency Action Plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, and notification of local e

mergency response agencies and the public.

To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place.


7.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program.  Recommendations resulting from the PHA and will be addressed in a timely manner.


8.  SEISMIC ASSESSMENT

As part of the CalARP program, Saputo is required to conduct a seismic assessment to evaluate the structural integrity of the refrigeration system.  The findings from the study will be used to improve the system in order to prevent or mitigate the effects of an ammonia release with offsite consequences in the event of an earthquake.
